Award.AwardTitle: TWC: Small: Imparting Privacy to Biometric Data in Cyberspace

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent work has established the possibility of deriving auxiliary information from biometric data. For example, it has been shown that face images can be used to deduce the health, gender, age and race of a subject; further, face images have been used to link a pseudonymous profile in the Web with a true profile, thereby compromising the privacy of an individual. The objective of this work is to design and implement techniques for imparting privacy to biometric data such as face, fingerprint and iris images.

In this regard, the following tasks are being conducted: (a) methods to modify biometric data such that the modified data can be used for re-identifying an individual but cannot be used to derive auxiliary information about the subject, such as gender and age; (b) methods to generate multiple privacy-enhanced templates from the same biometric data in such a way that these templates cannot be linked using a biometric matcher; and (c) methods to decompose and store the biometric data of a subject across entities such that individual entities cannot determine the identity of the subject, but collaboration across entities is essential for eliciting the identity of the subject. Finally, methods to assess the degree of privacy of a biometric image are being developed in order to quantify the amount of private information that can be derived from it. The proposed methods are being evaluated on publicly available face, fingerprint and iris datasets in order to determine their efficacy in the context of cyberspace applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to impart privacy to face images. Face images are being used in a number of applications for recognizing individuals. For example, some smartphones use faces for authenticating users. However, certain sensitive attributes of an individual can also be automatically gleaned from face images using machine learning techniques. Examples of such attributes include age, gender, race, and health cues. In this project, we designed a method to modify face images so that sensitive attributes cannot be automatically extracted from them. At the same time, the perturbed face image can be successfuly used for the intended purpose of biometric recognition. In addition, the project designed methods to impart controllable privacy, where users could specify which attributes to retain and which ones to suppress. Extensive experiments were conducted to evaluate the efficacy of the proposed method. 

The method itself was based on a type of neural network known as an AutoEncoder. The novelty of the method was in the design and training of the AutoEncoder as a "semi-adversarial" network in order to impart the desired functionality. The resulting network was termed as "PrivacyNet".  

The outcomes of this work were presented in various venues in order to promote the need for privacy. Furthermore, several peer-reviewed scientific publications were produced in order to inform the broader research community of methods that can be used to impart privacy. The project investigator also discussed the impact of biometric technology on personal privacy at the NATO Advanced Research Workshop on Identity and Security in Lausanne, Switzerland, in July 2018.
